subject: Re: [junit] Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or IsCollection.isEmpty()
msgSnippet: I think it s more a matter of someone producing a plausible implementation, rather than voting. My only caveat is to remember the years of my life that I lost
messageBody:
I think it's more a matter of someone producing a plausible
implementation, rather than voting. My only caveat is to remember the
years of my life that I lost to fighting Java generics to get as far
as we did in Hamcrest. I think C# has the advantage on us here.

S

On 19 May 2009, at 16:24, David Saff wrote:
>>> I'd love a vote on this matter. I'm imagining a tool that would
>>> generate code to provide special-case overloads for any final class,
>>> with String as the first use. Also, wrappers for all primitive types
>>> and boolean operators, to allow
>>>
>>> assertThat(5).greaterThan(4);
>>
>> This idea stands well on its own merits, and the notation does have
>> some
>> obvious benefits over the Hamcrest notation. However, I have one
>> burning question: why not continue to improve Hamcrest? While the
>> notation is not stellar, it does get the job done and seems to have
>> all
>> the relevant error reporting implemented.
>
> It's not a matter of notation: it's the requirement to create,
> remember, and statically import a new matcher for every boolean
> expression.



Steve Freeman
